Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Hi guys üëã

While taking a few minutes to recover from a rough week at work I'd like to tell you a story that relates to you.

It shows some of the character of the people here and makes me even more proud of what we've got and what we are doing.

For the last 6 weeks I've been out and about, meeting many other projects and people involved with blockchain and crypto.  The amount of lame 'tech' and blatant scams I've seen is quite eye opening. 

Certainly some naivety on my part.  That's what working with people like you, who are busting their asses to create real and valuable things, has done to me.  I was thinking that what we are doing here is normal.  It's not.

This experience has had me thinking a lot.

There is great demand in big-business for what we already have, not to mention what is well along in development. Some very smart people find it hard to believe that what we are doing could be possible.  They only dream of having things that we have already had in production for months and months.

Komodo, and what we work on here in KMDLabs, is building towards something big.  And it's thanks to people like you that it will get there.

Very glad to be here.

Content:

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Maybe we could end up with an example usecase, or even better, something you could use.

Author: CMaurice#1685
Content: I've sort of changed my mind recently about what are the best ideas going forward, have something that I should write up in the next week or so: again, nothing astoundingly imaginative and something many others are working on in the blockchain world

Author: CMaurice#1685
Content: but it's shoehorning something into blockchain that doesn't quite fit and I want to ruminate  a bit about whether problems can be surmounted

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: üÜí Would be interesting to hear your thoughts when your ready!

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: defining what is better in DB vs oracle is a fine art tho. wholesale migration to pure oracles is less than ideal.

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: all of that is awesome!

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: basically, oracles are best for static data in chronological order. if values need to change, use a db, else you just spam up the chain

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: So for transactional data, that wont be changed and eventually parsed out to historical chains, oracles work.

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: What about config values that need to live and breathe?

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: contracts?

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: you can get around the chronological a bit with an index, and I've made a migration tool for archiving oracles/data to feed into a fresh chain if bloat becomes an issue

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: immutable ledger means storing variable data can lead to a lot of stale info. Unless you need it for historical purposes to show how and when it changed, DB is still probably better.

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: i suppose if the system had a module that easily migrated the chains to a new fresh chain, and then applied the newest configuration values, and did it easily, that would work

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: oracle can work hand in hand with db tho

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: provides redundancy and validation

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: Chains with oracles dont need to change so no time there.... just the config based changes get replaced... mini hard forks

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: you could even get fancy with elastic clusters

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: oooooo now we talking fancy lol... scalability
